PHYSICS.content:
THE UNITED REPUBLIC OF TANZANIA
NATIONAL EXAMINATIONS COUNCIL OF TANZANIA
031 PHYSICS – THEORY PAPER 1
Time: 3 Hours

Instructions:
1. Answer ALL questions in Sections A and B and TWO (2) questions from Section C.
2. Write your Examination Number at the top right corner of every page.
3. Show clearly all working; credit will be given for steps.
4. Non‑programmable calculators and Physics tables may be used where necessary.
5. Write all answers in the spaces provided.

SECTION A (16 Marks)
Answer ALL questions in this section.

1. For each of the items (i)–(x), choose the correct answer and write its letter beside the item number.

   (i) The SI unit of force is
   - A. Joule
   - B. Newton
   - C. Pascal
   - D. Watt

   (ii) The device used to measure electric current is
   - A. Voltmeter
   - B. Ammeter
   - C. Ohmmeter
   - D. Galvanometer

   (iii) A body moving with constant speed in a straight line has
   - A. Zero acceleration
   - B. Increasing velocity
   - C. Decreasing speed
   - D. Variable acceleration

   (iv) The law of reflection states that the angle of incidence is equal to
   - A. angle of refraction
   - B. angle of deviation
   - C. angle of reflection
   - D. angle of emergence

   (v) In the absence of air resistance, all objects near Earth’s surface fall with the same
   - A. speed
   - B. velocity
   - C. acceleration due to gravity
   - D. momentum

   (vi) The ratio of useful energy output to total energy input is called
   - A. power
   - B. efficiency
   - C. work
   - D. force

   (vii) The force which opposes motion between two surfaces in contact is called
   - A. buoyancy
   - B. tension
   - C. friction
   - D. weight

   (viii) A transformer is used to
   - A. increase power
   - B. decrease resistance
   - C. change alternating voltage
   - D. measure current

   (ix) The pressure of a liquid depends on
   - A. density and temperature
   - B. density and depth
   - C. depth and volume
   - D. volume and temperature

   (x) The part of the eye that focuses light on the retina is the
   - A. iris
   - B. lens
   - C. cornea
   - D. pupil

2. Match the items in List A with responses in List B.

   List A
   (i) Speed
   (ii) Momentum
   (iii) Work
   (iv) Power
   (v) Archimedes’ principle
   (vi) Newton’s Third Law

   List B
   A. Product of force and displacement
   B. Force × distance/time
   C. Mass × velocity
   D. Rate of doing work
   E. Buoyant force equals weight of fluid displaced
   F. Every action has an equal and opposite reaction

SECTION B (54 Marks)
Answer ALL questions in this section.

3. (a) Define speed and velocity.
   (b) A car travels 150 m in 15 s. Calculate its speed.

4. (a) State Newton’s second law of motion.
   (b) A force of 20 N produces acceleration of 4 m/s² on a body. Find its mass.

5. (a) Define pressure in liquids.
   (b) A liquid of density 1000 kg/m³ exerts 4900 N/m² pressure at a certain depth. Find the depth.

6. (a) Explain the difference between series and parallel circuits.
   (b) Three resistors 2 Ω, 3 Ω and 5 Ω are connected in series across 10 V. Calculate total resistance and current.

7. (a) Define work and energy.
   (b) A 50 N force moves an object 4 m in direction of force. Calculate the work done.

8. (a) State the law of conservation of energy.
   (b) A 2 kg mass is lifted 5 m above the ground. Find its potential energy (g = 10 m/s²).

9. (a) Explain how a convex lens forms a real image when object is beyond 2F.
   (b) Draw a simple labelled ray diagram.

10. (a) Define simple harmonic motion.
     (b) A mass‑spring system has spring constant 200 N/m and mass 0.5 kg. Calculate period of oscillation.

SECTION C (30 Marks)
Answer any TWO questions.

11. (a) Derive the suvat equation v² = u² + 2as.
     (b) A car starting from rest accelerates at 3 m/s² for 8 s. Find final velocity and distance travelled.

12. (a) Describe with a labelled diagram how to determine the focal length of a convex lens using a distant object.
     (b) In an experiment, the distance between the lens and screen is 22 cm. Estimate the focal length.

13. (a) Explain the principle of moments.
     (b) A seesaw of length 4 m has pivot at centre; a 30 kg child sits at one end. Find the force needed 1 m from pivot on opposite side to balance it (g = 10 m/s²).

Answers.content:
SECTION A

1. Multiple choice answers with explanations:
(i) B. Newton — Force is measured in newtons (N) in SI.
(ii) B. Ammeter — Measures current when connected in series.
(iii) A. Zero acceleration — Constant speed in straight line means no change in velocity.
(iv) C. Angle of reflection — Law of reflection: angle of incidence = angle of reflection.
(v) C. Acceleration due to gravity — In vacuum, all objects fall with g ≈ 9.8 m/s².
(vi) B. Efficiency — Useful output/input ×100%.
(vii) C. Friction — Opposes motion between surfaces.
(viii) C. Change alternating voltage — Transformers change AC voltage.
(ix) B. Density and depth — Pressure in fluid: p = ρgh.
(x) B. Lens — Lens focuses light on retina.

2. Matching answers:
(i) Speed → — [v=distance/time] item related to motion; (Speed not in List B so matched as metric concept, but correct matching uses: (ii) Momentum → C; (iii) Work → A; (iv) Power → D; (v) Archimedes’ → E; (vi) Newton’s Third → F)

Explanation for matching:
- Momentum (C) = m × v.
- Work (A) = force × displacement.
- Power (D) = rate of doing work.
- Archimedes’ principle (E): buoyant force equals weight of fluid displaced.
- Newton’s third law (F): action = opposite reaction.

SECTION B

3. (a) Speed = distance/time; velocity = speed in a given direction.
(b) Speed = 150/15 = 10 m/s.

4. (a) Newton’s second law: F=ma.
(b) m = F/a = 20/4 = 5 kg.

5. (a) Pressure in liquids = force per unit area.
(b) p = ρgh → 4900 = 1000 × 10 × h → h = 0.49 m.

6. (a) Series: same current, add resistances; parallel: same voltage, reciprocal resistances.
(b) R_total=2+3+5=10Ω; I=V/R=10/10=1A.

7. (a) Work is energy transfer; energy is capacity to do work.
(b) W=50×4=200 J.

8. (a) Energy cannot be created/destroyed.
(b) PE=mgh=2×10×5=100J.

9. (a) Convex lens: real inverted image between F and 2F for object beyond 2F.
(b) (Diagram omitted but rays converge).

10. (a) SHM: restoring force ∝ displacement.
(b) T=2π√(m/k)=2π√(0.5/200)≈2π×√(0.0025)=2π×0.05≈0.314s.

SECTION C

11. (a) Standard SUVAT derivation: v=u+at; s=ut+½at²; eliminate t to get v²=u²+2as. (b) v=0+3×8=24m/s; s=0×8+½×3×64=96 m.

12. (a) Setup lens, screen, distant object; adjust screen for sharp image; measure lens‑screen distance≈f. (b) f≈22 cm.

13. (a) Moments: force×perpendicular distance about pivot. (b) Torque balance: 30×2 = F×1 → 60=F→ F=60N.

End of Answers.

CHEMISTRY.content:
THE UNITED REPUBLIC OF TANZANIA
NATIONAL EXAMINATIONS COUNCIL OF TANZANIA
FORM FOUR NATIONAL ASSESSMENT
032 CHEMISTRY – THEORY PAPER 1
Time: 3 Hours

Instructions:
1. Answer all questions in Sections A and B.
2. In Section C, answer only one (1) question.
3. Write all answers clearly in the spaces provided.
4. Use appropriate chemical symbols and formulae.
5. Calculators and mobile phones are not allowed.

SECTION A (15 Marks)
Answer all questions in this section.

1. For each of the items (i)–(x), choose the correct answer and write its letter beside the item number.
   (i) Matter is defined as
   - A. Something that has no mass and occupies space
   - B. Anything that has mass and occupies space
   - C. A form of energy
   - D. A mixture of gases

   (ii) Which of the following shows an element?
   - A. H2O
   - B. CO2
   - C. O2
   - D. NaCl

   (iii) The gas evolved when zinc reacts with hydrochloric acid is
   - A. Oxygen
   - B. Hydrogen
   - C. Nitrogen
   - D. Carbon dioxide

   (iv) Which of the following is a basic oxide?
   - A. CO2
   - B. SO2
   - C. CaO
   - D. NO2

   (v) The pH of pure water at 25°C is
   - A. 1
   - B. 7
   - C. 14
   - D. 0

   (vi) Electrolysis is defined as
   - A. Chemical change by heat
   - B. Chemical change by light
   - C. Chemical change by electricity
   - D. Physical change

   (vii) The mole concept is based on
   - A. Einstein number
   - B. Avogadro number
   - C. Faraday constant
   - D. Planck’s constant

   (viii) A covalent bond is formed by
   - A. Transfer of electrons
   - B. Sharing of electrons
   - C. Donation of protons
   - D. Movement of ions

   (ix) The law of conservation of mass states that
   - A. Mass is lost in a reaction
   - B. Mass cannot be created or destroyed
   - C. Mass is gained in a reaction
   - D. Mass changes during heating

   (x) Which process is used to separate a soluble solid from its solvent by evaporation?
   - A. Filtration
   - B. Distillation
   - C. Evaporation
   - D. Chromatography

2. Match the items in List A with the correct responses in List B.
   List A
   (i) Volumetric analysis
   (ii) Oxidation
   (iii) Distillation
   (iv) Solubility
   (v) Catalyst
   List B
   A. Ability of solute to dissolve in solvent
   B. Loss of electrons
   C. Substance that speeds up reaction without being consumed
   D. Separating liquids by boiling points
   E. Technique to find concentration of solutions

SECTION B (70 Marks)
Answer all questions in this section.

3. (a) Define matter and list its three states.
   (b) Give one example of each state.

4. (a) Explain how ionic bonds form using sodium chloride as an example.
   (b) Draw the Lewis (dot) diagram for a molecule of water (H2O).

5. (a) State Avogadro’s law.
   (b) A gas occupies 10 L at constant temperature and pressure. What volume will it occupy if the number of moles is doubled?

6. (a) Define acid and base according to Brønsted–Lowry theory.
   (b) A solution has a hydrogen ion concentration [H+] = 1 × 10^-4 M. Calculate the pH.

7. (a) Explain two factors that affect the rate of chemical reactions.
   (b) Suggest one practical way to increase the rate of a reaction.

8. (a) State the law of conservation of mass.
   (b) 2 g of hydrogen reacts with 16 g of oxygen to form water. Show that mass is conserved in this reaction.

9. (a) Define oxidation number.
   (b) Find the oxidation number of sulfur in H2SO4.

10. (a) Describe the electrolysis of molten sodium chloride.
     (b) State the products formed at the cathode and anode.

SECTION C (15 Marks)
Answer only one question.

11. (a) Describe how to prepare 500 cm³ of 1.0 M sodium hydroxide solution from solid NaOH.
     (b) Suggest three safety precautions when preparing chemical solutions.

12. (a) Explain the steps to standardise hydrochloric acid using sodium carbonate and methyl orange indicator.
     (b) Write the balanced chemical equation for the reaction.

13. (a) Explain three methods of preventing corrosion of iron.
     (b) Describe why dry conditions slow down corrosion.

Answers.content:
SECTION A

1. Multiple choice answers with explanations:

(i) B. Anything that has mass and occupies space — Matter is defined by having both mass and volume.

(ii) C. O2 — O2 is a molecule of elemental oxygen; H2O and NaCl are compounds.

(iii) B. Hydrogen — Reaction Zn + 2HCl → ZnCl2 + H2, hydrogen gas is evolved.

(iv) C. CaO — Calcium oxide is a basic oxide; CO2 and SO2 are acidic.

(v) B. 7 — Neutral solutions like pure water have pH of 7 at 25°C.

(vi) C. Chemical change by electricity — Electrolysis uses electrical energy to decompose substances.

(vii) B. Avogadro number — The mole concept uses 6.02 × 10^23 particles per mole.

(viii) B. Sharing of electrons — Covalent bonds form when atoms share electrons.

(ix) B. Mass cannot be created or destroyed — This is the law of conservation of mass.

(x) C. Evaporation — Evaporation separates a dissolved solid by removing the solvent.

2. Matching answers:
(i) E — Volumetric analysis: technique to find concentration of solutions.
(ii) B — Oxidation: loss of electrons.
(iii) D — Distillation: separating liquids by boiling points.
(iv) A — Solubility: ability of solute to dissolve.
(v) C — Catalyst: speeds up reaction without being consumed.

SECTION B

3. (a) Matter is anything that has mass and occupies space. Three states: solid, liquid, gas.
(b) Examples: Solid — iron; Liquid — water; Gas — oxygen.

4. (a) Ionic bonding: In NaCl, sodium atom loses one electron to chlorine atom. Na becomes Na+ and Cl becomes Cl−; the opposite charges attract forming ionic bond.
(b) Lewis diagram for H2O: O has 6 valence electrons (dots) and shares one electron with each H forming two covalent bonds.

5. (a) Avogadro’s law: At constant temperature and pressure, the volume of a gas is directly proportional to the number of moles.
(b) If number of moles doubles, volume doubles: 10 L × 2 = 20 L.

6. (a) Brønsted–Lowry acid: proton donor; base: proton acceptor.
(b) pH = -log[H+] = -log(1 × 10^-4) = 4.

7. (a) Factors affecting rate: concentration (higher increases collisions), temperature (higher increases kinetic energy), surface area (smaller pieces react faster), catalysts (lower activation energy).
(b) Increase temperature to speed up collisions.

8. (a) Law: mass of reactants = mass of products.
(b) 2 g H2 + 16 g O2 → 18 g H2O; mass before = 18 g, after = 18 g (conserved).

9. (a) Oxidation number: hypothetical charge if electrons were fully transferred.
(b) In H2SO4: H = +1 × 2 = +2; O = -2 × 4 = -8; let S = x: x +2 -8 = 0 → x = +6.

10. (a) Electrolysis of molten NaCl: Na+ ions go to cathode, gain electrons to form Na; Cl− ions go to anode, lose electrons to form Cl2 gas.
(b) Products: cathode — molten sodium; anode — chlorine gas.

SECTION C

11. (a) To prepare 500 cm³ of 1.0 M NaOH: Calculate moles needed: M × V = 1 × 0.5 = 0.5 mol. Mass = 0.5 × 40 = 20 g NaOH; dissolve in water and make up to 500 cm³.
(b) Safety: wear goggles and gloves; add NaOH to water slowly; label container.

12. (a) Standardising HCl: Weigh a known amount of Na2CO3, dissolve and titrate with HCl using methyl orange; record volumes at endpoint.
(b) Reaction: Na2CO3 + 2HCl → 2NaCl + H2O + CO2.

13. (a) Prevent corrosion: painting metal surfaces, galvanising with zinc, sacrificial anodes.
(b) Dry conditions slow corrosion because water is required to dissolve ions and facilitate electrochemical rusting.

BIOLOGY.content:
THE UNITED REPUBLIC OF TANZANIA
NATIONAL EXAMINATIONS COUNCIL OF TANZANIA
FORM FOUR NATIONAL ASSESSMENT
034 BIOLOGY – THEORY PAPER 3
Time: 3 Hours

Instructions:
1. Answer all questions in Sections A and B.
2. In Section C, answer any two (2) questions.
3. Write all answers clearly in the spaces provided.
4. Use scientific names where necessary.
5. Calculators and mobile phones are not allowed.

SECTION A (20 Marks)
Answer all questions.

1. For each of the items (i)–(x), choose the correct answer and write its letter beside the item number.

   (i) The structural unit of the kidney is called
   - A. Neuron
   - B. Nephron
   - C. Alveolus
   - D. Axon

   (ii) Which vitamin is essential for blood clotting?
   - A. Vitamin A
   - B. Vitamin C
   - C. Vitamin K
   - D. Vitamin D

   (iii) The hormone that stimulates milk production is
   - A. Oxytocin
   - B. Prolactin
   - C. Insulin
   - D. Adrenaline

   (iv) A plant that completes its life cycle in one year is called
   - A. Biennial
   - B. Annual
   - C. Perennial
   - D. Deciduous

   (v) Which blood cells are responsible for immunity?
   - A. Red blood cells
   - B. Platelets
   - C. White blood cells
   - D. Plasma

   (vi) The main excretory product in humans is
   - A. Oxygen
   - B. Urea
   - C. Glucose
   - D. Carbon dioxide

   (vii) Which of the following organisms are decomposers?
   - A. Bacteria and fungi
   - B. Algae and moss
   - C. Amoeba and paramecium
   - D. Grass and trees

   (viii) The process of water loss from plant leaves is called
   - A. Guttation
   - B. Evaporation
   - C. Transpiration
   - D. Condensation

   (ix) The sugar present in DNA is
   - A. Glucose
   - B. Fructose
   - C. Deoxyribose
   - D. Ribose

   (x) Which of the following is a nitrogen-fixing bacterium?
   - A. Escherichia coli
   - B. Rhizobium
   - C. Staphylococcus
   - D. Bacillus

2. Match the items in **List A** with **List B**.

   List A
   (i) Artery
   (ii) Vein
   (iii) Ligament
   (iv) Cerebrum
   (v) Spongy bone

   List B
   A. Connects bone to bone
   B. Carries blood away from the heart
   C. Light, porous bone found at ends of long bones
   D. Carries blood towards the heart
   E. Controls voluntary actions and intelligence

BAnswers.content:
SECTION A

1. Multiple choice answers with explanations:

(i) B. Nephron — The nephron is the functional unit of the kidney, responsible for filtering blood and forming urine.

(ii) C. Vitamin K — Vitamin K is essential for synthesizing prothrombin, necessary for blood clotting.

(iii) B. Prolactin — Stimulates milk production in the mammary glands.

(iv) B. Annual — Completes its life cycle (germination to seed) within one year.

(v) C. White blood cells — Defend the body against pathogens; part of immune system.

(vi) B. Urea — Main nitrogenous waste excreted in urine.

(vii) A. Bacteria and fungi — Decomposers break down dead organic matter, returning nutrients to soil.

(viii) C. Transpiration — Loss of water vapor from stomata in leaves, important for water movement and cooling.

(ix) C. Deoxyribose — Sugar component of DNA nucleotides.

(x) B. Rhizobium — Symbiotic bacteria in legume root nodules that fix atmospheric nitrogen.

2. Matching:

(i) B — Artery carries blood away from the heart.
(ii) D — Vein carries blood towards the heart.
(iii) A — Ligament connects bone to bone.
(iv) E — Cerebrum controls voluntary actions, intelligence, memory.
(v) C — Spongy bone is light, porous, and found at ends of long bones.

SECTION B (50 Marks)

3. Excretion
(a) Human excretory system: kidneys, ureters, bladder, urethra.
(b) Functions: remove nitrogenous wastes, maintain osmotic balance, regulate pH.

4. Nutrition
(a) Types: autotrophic (plants), heterotrophic (animals, fungi).
(b) Digestion: mechanical (chewing), chemical (enzymes breaking down food).

5. Respiration
(a) Aerobic: glucose + oxygen → carbon dioxide + water + energy.
(b) Anaerobic: glucose → lactic acid + energy (humans); glucose → ethanol + CO2 + energy (yeast).

6. Transport in humans
(a) Blood: plasma, RBCs, WBCs, platelets.
(b) Function: transport oxygen, nutrients, hormones, waste.

7. Nervous system
(a) Neuron: dendrites, cell body, axon, synaptic terminals.
(b) Reflex action: rapid, involuntary response to stimuli.

8. Reproduction
(a) Sexual reproduction produces genetic variation.
(b) Fertilization restores diploid number, initiates zygote development.

9. Ecology
(a) Biotic and abiotic components; population, community, ecosystem.
(b) Food chains/webs; energy flow; importance of decomposers.

10. Human health
(a) Diseases: infectious (malaria, TB) vs deficiency (rickets, goitre).
(b) Prevention: hygiene, vaccination, balanced diet.

SECTION B (54 Marks)
Answer all questions in this section.

3. (a) Define Geography and describe two major branches of Geography.

4. (a) Describe how relief features such as mountains and valleys are represented on a topographic map.

Answer any TWO questions.

9. (a) Explain how to conduct simple field survey and map making in a local area. Include steps and instruments used.

10. (a) Discuss the factors that influence agricultural activities in Tanzania.

BUSINESS_STUDIES.content:
THE UNITED REPUBLIC OF TANZANIA
NATIONAL EXAMINATIONS COUNCIL OF TANZANIA
FORM FOUR NATIONAL ASSESSMENT
065 BUSINESS STUDIES – THEORY PAPER 2
Time: 3 Hours

Instructions:
1. This paper consists of Sections A, B and C.
2. Answer all questions in Sections A and B.

4. Write all answers clearly in the spaces provided.
5. Calculators and mobile phones are not allowed.

SECTION A (15 Marks)
Answer all questions in this section.

1. For each of items (i)–(x), choose the correct answer and write its letter beside the item number.

   (i) A business plan is important because it
   - A. records daily sales only
   - B. helps in planning for the business
   - C. prevents competition
   - D. increases expenses

   (ii) A fixed asset is

   - B. stock for sale
   - C. machinery used in business
   - D. accounts payable

   (iii) Market segmentation is the process of

   - D. creating jobs

   (iv) Insurance protects a business against
   - A. theft only
   - B. accident and risks
   - C. profit loss only
   - D. market demand

   (v) Working capital refers to
   - A. long‑term funds
   - B. money invested in fixed assets
   - C. funds available for day‑to‑day operations

   (vi) A memorandum of association is related to
   - A. partnerships
   - B. sole proprietorship
   - C. company registration
   - D. tax documents

   (vii) A cheque is used to
   - A. deposit goods
   - B. withdraw or transfer money
   - C. issue invoice
   - D. record transactions

   (viii) The main purpose of advertising is to
   - A. reduce supply
   - B. inform and attract customers
   - C. increase production cost
   - D. limit competition

   (ix) Price elasticity of demand measures
   - A. change in supply
   - B. responsiveness of quantity demanded to price change
   - C. cost of production
   - D. income level only

   (x) Ethical business practice requires
   - A. ignoring customer complaints
   - B. truth in advertising

2. Match the items in List A with those in List B.

   List A
   (i) Profit margin
   (ii) Balance Sheet
   (iii) Cash flow
   (iv) Human resource management
   (v) Stock control

   List B
   A. Management of employees
   B. Financial statement showing assets and liabilities
   C. Difference between selling price and cost expressed as percentage
   D. Management of goods available for sale
   E. Movement of money in and out of business

SECTION B (70 Marks)
Answer all questions in this section.

3. (a) Define *business environment*.
   (b) Explain three factors that influence business environment.

4. (a) What is meant by *trade credit*?
   (b) Explain two advantages of trade credit to a business.

5. (a) Define *bank overdraft*.
   (b) Give one advantage and one disadvantage of bank overdraft.

6. (a) Explain the concept of *marketing mix*.
   (b) Discuss the importance of product in the marketing mix.

7. (a) What is *customer relationship management (CRM)*?
   (b) Explain two ways a business can maintain good CRM.

8. (a) Define *operational planning*.
   (b) Describe two tools used in planning.

9. (a) Explain what is meant by *franchising*.
   (b) Give two advantages of franchising to the franchisee.

10. (a) Define *inventory control*.
     (b) Explain two methods of inventory control.

SECTION C (15 Marks)
Answer any TWO questions.

11. (a) Explain the role of entrepreneurship in national development.
     (b) Discuss three ways in which government supports small businesses.

12. (a) Describe how *e‑commerce* has changed business operations.
     (b) Explain two challenges businesses face when adopting e‑commerce.

13. (a) Define *corporate social responsibility (CSR)*.
     (b) Explain three benefits of CSR to a business.

BUAnswers.content:
SECTION A

1. Multiple choice answers with explanations:

(i) B. Helps in planning for the business — A business plan guides objectives and strategies.

(ii) C. Machinery used in business — Fixed assets are long‑term business assets.

(iii) A. Dividing market into groups — Segmentation groups customers with shared characteristics.

(iv) B. Accident and risks — Insurance protects against specified risks.

(v) C. Funds available for day‑to‑day operations — Working capital funds daily operations.

(vi) C. Company registration — Memorandum of association is part of company formation.

(vii) B. Withdraw or transfer money — Cheques instruct banks to pay.

(viii) B. Inform and attract customers — Advertising promotes products.

(ix) B. Responsiveness of quantity demanded to price change — Price elasticity of demand measures this.

(x) B. Truth in advertising — Ethical practice means honesty and fairness.

2. Matching answers:
(i) C — Profit margin = difference between selling price and cost as a percentage.
(ii) B — Balance sheet = statement showing assets and liabilities.
(iii) E — Cash flow = movement of money in/out.
(iv) A — Human resource management = employee management.
(v) D — Stock control = managing goods for sale.


SECTION B

3. (a) Business environment is the combination of internal and external forces affecting business operations.
   (b) Factors: Economic conditions (inflation, interest rates), social/cultural values (consumer preferences), technological changes (new production methods).

4. (a) Trade credit is credit given by suppliers allowing delayed payment.
   (b) Advantages: Improves cash flow and allows business to stock more; encourages volume purchasing.

5. (a) Bank overdraft is short‑term credit allowing customers to withdraw more than their bank balance.
   (b) Advantage: Immediate access to cash; Disadvantage: High interest cost.

6. (a) Marketing mix is combination of product, price, place and promotion strategies.
   (b) Importance of product: Central to satisfying customer needs and differentiating from competitors.

7. (a) CRM is managing interactions with customers to build loyalty.
   (b) Ways: Respond promptly to complaints; personalise customer communication.

8. (a) Operational planning sets detailed plans for day‑to‑day activities.
   (b) Tools: SWOT analysis (strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, threats); Gantt charts for scheduling.

9. (a) Franchising is a business arrangement where one business (franchisor) allows another (franchisee) to use its brand and model.
   (b) Advantages: Established brand reputation, training and support.

10. (a) Inventory control is managing stock levels efficiently.
     (b) Methods: FIFO (first in first out); JIT (just‑in‑time) inventory.


SECTION C

11. (a) Entrepreneurship drives national development by creating jobs, contributing to GDP, and fostering innovation.
     (b) Government support: Provide microloans, tax incentives for SMEs, business training programmes.

12. (a) E‑commerce has changed business operations by enabling online sales and expanding market reach.
     (b) Challenges: Cybersecurity risks; Internet connectivity issues.

13. (a) CSR is a business’s responsibility towards society and environment.
     (b) Benefits: Enhances reputation, builds customer trust, improves employee morale.

End of Answers.

HISTORY.content:
THE UNITED REPUBLIC OF TANZANIA
NATIONAL EXAMINATIONS COUNCIL OF TANZANIA
FORM FOUR NATIONAL ASSESSMENT
012 HISTORY
(For Both School and Private Candidates)
Time: 3 Hours

Instructions:
1. Answer all questions in Sections A and B.
2. In Section C answer any three (3) questions.
3. All writing must be in blue or black ink.
4. Drawings and maps must be in pencil.
5. Write your Assessment Number at the top right corner of every page.

SECTION A (20 Marks)
Answer all questions in this section.

1. (a) For each of items (i)–(x), choose the correct answer and write its letter beside the item number.
   (i) One of the primary sources of historical information is
   - A. Museum archives
   - B. Oral traditions
   - C. History textbooks
   - D. Encyclopedias

   (ii) The earliest humans are believed to have appeared in
   - A. Asia
   - B. Europe
   - C. Africa
   - D. South America

   (iii) The Berlin Conference of 1884–85 is significant in African history because
   - A. It granted independence to African colonies
   - B. It ended slavery in Africa
   - C. It regulated European colonization of Africa
   - D. It formed the African Union

   (iv) Which of the following was a factor in the colonization of Africa?
   - A. Industrial revolution
   - B. Renaissance
   - C. World War II
   - D. Cold War

   (v) The term *nationalism* in African history refers to
   - A. Loyalty to European rulers
   - B. Desire for independence from colonial rule
   - C. Promotion of tribal wars
   - D. Adoption of foreign cultures

   (vi) The policy of apartheid was implemented in
   - A. Kenya
   - B. Ghana
   - C. South Africa
   - D. Egypt

   (vii) Which organisation was formed to promote unity among African states?
   - A. ASEAN
   - B. OAU (Organisation of African Unity)
   - C. EU
   - D. NATO

   (viii) The first President of independent Ghana was
   - A. Nelson Mandela
   - B. Julius Nyerere
   - C. Kwame Nkrumah
   - D. Jomo Kenyatta

   (ix) A notable economic impact of colonial rule was
   - A. Industrial self–sufficiency in Africa
   - B. Development of cash crop economy
   - C. Equal trade relations
   - D. Preservation of traditional crafts

   (x) After independence, many African states faced challenges such as
   - A. Political stability
   - B. Unity among tribes
   - C. Economic dependency
   - D. All of the above

1. (b) Match the items in **List A** with correct responses in **List B**.
   List A
   (i) Pre‑colonial African economy
   (ii) Colonial administrative system
   (iii) Atlantic slave trade
   (iv) Decolonization
   (v) Pan‑Africanism

   List B
   A. Movement for African political unity
   B. Forced export of African slaves to the Americas
   C. Traditional systems before European rule
   D. Policies of colonial governance
   E. Struggle for independence

SECTION B (35 Marks)
Answer all questions in this section.

2. (a) Define *history*.
   (b) Explain two reasons why the study of history is important.

3. (a) Describe the contributions of oral traditions to the study of African history.
   (b) Give one limitation of using oral traditions as a historical source.

4. (a) Explain two economic effects of colonial rule in Africa.
   (b) Describe one social impact of colonial education.

5. (a) Outline three major causes of the scramble for Africa.
   (b) Explain one consequence of the Berlin Conference on African societies.

SECTION C (45 Marks)
Answer any three questions.

6. (a) Describe the origins and development of nationalism in Ghana.
   (b) Explain how nationalism contributed to Ghana’s independence.

7. (a) Discuss the impact of the First World War on the rise of African nationalist movements.
   (b) Explain how African ex‑soldiers influenced decolonisation efforts.

8. (a) Explain the role of the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) in promoting African unity.
   (b) Evaluate the successes and limitations of OAU.

9. (a) Describe the causes of political instability in post‑independence African states.

ENGLISH.content:
THE UNITED REPUBLIC OF TANZANIA
NATIONAL EXAMINATIONS COUNCIL OF TANZANIA
FORM FOUR CERTIFICATE OF SECONDARY EDUCATION EXAMINATION (CSEE)
022 ENGLISH LANGUAGE
(For both School and Private Candidates)
Time: 3 Hours

Instructions:
1. This paper consists of three sections: A, B and C.
2. Answer all questions in Section A and B, and any three questions from Section C.
3. All answers must be written clearly in the spaces provided.
4. Dictionaries are not allowed.

SECTION A (15 Marks)
Answer all questions in this section.

1. Multiple Choice Questions (Choose the correct answer)

   (i) The synonym of 'diligent' is
   - A. Lazy
   - B. Hardworking
   - C. Careless
   - D. Negligent

   (ii) Choose the correct sentence
   - A. She have finished her homework.
   - B. She has finished her homework.
   - C. She have finish her homework.
   - D. She has finish her homework.

   (iii) Passive form: 'The teacher is marking the books.'
   - A. The books are being marked by the teacher.
   - B. The books is being marked by the teacher.
   - C. The books were being marked by the teacher.
   - D. The books is marked by the teacher.

   (iv) Correct spelling
   - A. Recieve
   - B. Receive
   - C. Recive
   - D. Recieive

   (v) Meaning of idiom 'Break the ice'
   - A. Start a conversation
   - B. Break something
   - C. Relax completely
   - D. End a relationship

2. Matching Items

   List A:
   (i) Simile
   (ii) Metaphor
   (iii) Onomatopoeia
   (iv) Hyperbole
   (v) Personification

   List B:
   A. Giving human qualities to non-human things
   B. Exaggeration for effect
   C. A comparison using 'like' or 'as'
   D. Words that imitate sounds
   E. A direct comparison without using 'like' or 'as'

SECTION B (40 Marks)
Answer all questions in this section.

3. Comprehension Passage:

"Technology has revolutionized the way people communicate. With the advent of the internet, social media, and mobile phones, information can be shared instantly across the world. This has made education, business, and personal relationships more efficient and dynamic."

   (a) What is the main idea of the passage?
   (b) List two ways technology has improved human life according to the passage.

4. Correct the errors:

   (a) He don’t know the answer.
   (b) I am going to the market yesterday.

5. Fill in the blanks:

   (a) She sings very ___________ (beautiful) in the choir.
   (b) They were asked to ___________ (complete) the assignment on time.

6. Write a short dialogue (about 50 words) between a shopkeeper and a customer buying a school uniform.

7. Change to reported speech:

   (a) Peter said, "I am feeling sick today."
   (b) Sarah said, "I will come to the party on Saturday."

SECTION C (45 Marks)
Answer any three questions.

8. Essay of about 150–200 words on: "The effects of social media on youth."

9. Composition of about 150–200 words describing your favourite hobby and its importance.

10. Read the poem:

"The wind whispers through the trees,
Carrying secrets with gentle ease.
Leaves dance under moonlit skies,
Nature's beauty before our eyes."

   (a) What is the theme of the poem?
   (b) Identify two literary devices used in the poem.

11. Story writing: Complete the story beginning "The old house at the end of the street had always been mysterious, but tonight..."

EAnswers.content:
SECTION A

1. Multiple Choice Answers

(i) B. Hardworking — 'Diligent' means hardworking.
(ii) B. She has finished her homework. — Correct subject-verb agreement.
(iii) A. The books are being marked by the teacher. — Correct passive form.
(iv) B. Receive — Correct spelling.
(v) A. Start a conversation — Meaning of 'Break the ice'.

2. Matching Items

(i) C — Simile: comparison using 'like' or 'as'.
(ii) E — Metaphor: direct comparison without 'like' or 'as'.
(iii) D — Onomatopoeia: words that imitate sounds.
(iv) B — Hyperbole: exaggeration for effect.
(v) A — Personification: giving human qualities to non-human things.

SECTION B

3. Comprehension

(a) Main idea: Technology has changed communication worldwide.
(b) Two ways: Sharing information instantly; improving education, business, and personal relationships.

4. Correct the errors

(a) He doesn’t know the answer.
(b) I went to the market yesterday.

5. Fill in the blanks

(a) beautifully
(b) complete

6. Sample dialogue:

Shopkeeper: Good morning! How can I help you?
Customer: I would like to buy a school uniform for my son.
Shopkeeper: Sure, what size does he wear?
Customer: Size 14, please.
Shopkeeper: Here you go. Will you need shoes as well?
Customer: Yes, please.

7. Reported speech

(a) Peter said that he was feeling sick that day.
(b) Sarah said that she would come to the party on Saturday.

SECTION C

8. Essay sample points:
- Social media connects people.
- Can improve learning and access to information.
- May cause distraction and addiction.
- Promotes communication skills.

9. Composition sample points:
- Hobby: Reading, football, music, etc.
- Benefits: Improves skills, provides relaxation, promotes creativity.

10. Poem

(a) Theme: Beauty and tranquility of nature.
(b) Literary devices: Personification ('wind whispers'), Alliteration ('leaves dance').

11. Story sample:

"The old house at the end of the street had always been mysterious, but tonight I saw lights flickering inside. Curious, I stepped closer and heard faint whispers. Summoning courage, I opened the creaky door and found a hidden library filled with ancient books. The discovery would change my life forever."
